context.text: In other pattern recognition fields, such as speech and optical character recognition, significant progresses have been made since large corpora of training and test data are publicly available and public competitions are organized to compare recognition techniques on a fair basis [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8].

paperAbstract.text: A database of continuous read speech has been designed and recorded within the DARPA strategic computing speech recognition program. The data is intended for use in designing and evaluating algorithms for speaker-independent, speaker-adaptive and speaker-dependent speech recognition. The data consists of read sentences appropriate to a naval resource management task built around existing interactive database and graphics programs. The 1000-word task vocabulary is intended to be logically complete and habitable. The database, which represents over 21000 recorded utterances from 160 talkers with a variety of dialects, includes a partition of sentences and talkers for training and for testing purposes.<<ETX>>

title.text: The DARPA 1000-word resource management database for continuous speech recognition

tldr.text: A database of continuous read speech has been designed and recorded within the DARPA strategic computing speech recognition program for use in designing and evaluating algorithms for speaker-independent, speaker-adaptive and speaker-dependent speech recognition.

venue.text: ICASSP-88., International Conference on Acoustics, Speech, and Signal Processing

context.text: In other pattern recognition fields, such as speech and optical character recognition, significant progresses have been made since large corpora of training and test data are publicly available and public competitions are organized to compare recognition techniques on a fair basis [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8].

paperAbstract.text: Producing a database of scanned document images for development or evaluation of OCR and document image understanding algorithms is neither easy nor inexpensive. The authors first briefly describe the makeup of a database of scanned document images of scientific and technical documents written in English which are being produced in a CD-ROM format. Then, the authors concentrate on the implementation methodology used to prepare the database. The methodology gives the protocols for each step of the database preparation, and the error model used for the estimation of the ground-truth errors that may exist in the database is discussed.<<ETX>>

title.text: The implementation methodology for a CD-ROM English document database

tldr.text: The authors first briefly describe the makeup of a database of scanned document images of scientific and technical documents written in English which are being produced in a CD-ROM format and concentrate on the implementation methodology used to prepare the database.

venue.text: Proceedings of 2nd International Conference on Document Analysis and Recognition (ICDAR '93)

context.text: In other pattern recognition fields, such as speech and optical character recognition, significant progresses have been made since large corpora of training and test data are publicly available and public competitions are organized to compare recognition techniques on a fair basis [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8].

paperAbstract.text: SWITCHBOARD is a large multispeaker corpus of conversational speech and text which should be of interest to researchers in speaker authentication and large vocabulary speech recognition. About 2500 conversations by 500 speakers from around the US were collected automatically over T1 lines at Texas Instruments. Designed for training and testing of a variety of speech processing algorithms, especially in speaker verification, it has over an 1 h of speech from each of 50 speakers, and several minutes each from hundreds of others. A time-aligned word for word transcription accompanies each recording.<<ETX>>

title.text: SWITCHBOARD: telephone speech corpus for research and development

venue.text: [Proceedings] ICASSP-92: 1992 IEEE International Conference on Acoustics, Speech, and Signal Processing

context.text: In other pattern recognition fields, such as speech and optical character recognition, significant progresses have been made since large corpora of training and test data are publicly available and public competitions are organized to compare recognition techniques on a fair basis [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8].

paperAbstract.text: Methodologies and techniques for constructing document image databases are discussed. Specific experience and considerations in creating a database for handwriting recognition research are presented. Practical considerations, including the choice of an image digitizer for such a database are presented. Examples of existing databases for handwriting recognition research are discussed. Also, various issues in testing pattern recognition algorithms and how they apply to database design are presented.

title.text: Large Database Organization for Document Images

tldr.text: Practical considerations, including the choice of an image digitizer for such a database are presented, and various issues in testing pattern recognition algorithms and how they apply to database design are presented.

context.text: In other pattern recognition fields, such as speech and optical character recognition, significant progresses have been made since large corpora of training and test data are publicly available and public competitions are organized to compare recognition techniques on a fair basis [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8].

paperAbstract.text: Speech research has made tremendous progress in the past using the following paradigm:• define the research problem,• collect a corpus to objectively measure progress, and• solve the research problem.Natural language research, on the other hand, has typically progressed without the benefit of any corpus of data with which to test research hypotheses. We describe the Air Travel Information System (ATIS) pilot corpus, a corpus designed to measure progress in Spoken Language Systems that include both a speech and natural language component. This pilot marks the first full-scale attempt to collect such a corpus and provides guidelines for future efforts.

title.text: The ATIS Spoken Language Systems Pilot Corpus

tldr.text: This pilot marks the first full-scale attempt to collect a corpus to measure progress in Spoken Language Systems that include both a speech and natural language component and provides guidelines for future efforts.

context.text: After the benchmark, the data will be open to the public and distributed by LDC.

A first test is currently organized jointly by the Technical Committee 11 of the International Association of Pattern Recognition, the Linguistic Data Consortium (LDC) [10] and the US National Institute of Standards and Technologies (NIST).
The data received from participants will be complemented with training data collected by LDC.
Participants providing more than 50,000 characters will receive a money compensation from LDC.
Deprived of class labels, the test sets will be made available by NIST, at the LDC FTP site.

context.text: The format incorporates features from the internal formats of IBM, Apple(Tap), Microsoft, Slate (Jot), HP, AT&T, NICI, GO, CIC.

In contrast with binary formats, such as Jot [9], the UNIPEN format is not optimized for data storage or real time data transmission and it is not designed to handle ink manipulation applications involving colors, image rotations, rescaling, etc.
